channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: A Pioneer of Street Photography Leaves Behind Strong Images of Indian Women
item.description: Pranlal Patel, who recently died at the age of 104 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, was one of the first photographers in India to capture women at work in the public space.
item.dc:creator: By ZAHIR JANMOHAMED

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Times Now Editor in Chief Arnab Goswami
item.description: India Ink spoke with the journalist, who landed the first TV interview with Rahul Gandhi of the Congress Party, about the reasons behind his line of questioning and why the interview was important to the public.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Arnab Goswami, editor in chief, Times Now television news channel.

item.title: Report Says Afghanistan Can’t Be Trusted to Prevent Misuse of U.S. Aid
item.description: The report by the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction raises new questions about the wisdom of giving extensive aid directly to a government known for corruption.
item.category: Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and AZAM AHMED

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pet Owners Brace for Chinese New Year Fireworks
item.description: Although Lunar New Year fireworks are considered a sound of celebration and a deterrent to evil spirits, many pet owners say their dogs and cats are terrified during the two-week barrage of pyrotechnics.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:credit: Keith Bedford for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man hauls discarded boxes of fireworks in Beijing during the Chinese New Year in 2011.

item.title: Pakistani Premier Forms Group to Start Talks With Taliban
item.description: The move, coming soon after terrorist attacks and government retaliation, was a surprise to many, and there was doubt about the group’s prospects for success.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: World Briefing: Obama to Meet Jordanian King
item.description: President Obama host King Abdullah II of Jordan next month at Sunnylands, a sprawling desert estate in Rancho Mirage, Calif.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Warrantless Surveillance Challenged by Defendant
item.description: The challenge by a Colorado resident who was charged with terrorism-related offenses could lead to a Supreme Court test of a National Security Agency program.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Jamshid Muhtorov, with his wife and children in 2012, faces terrorism-related charges and was told by prosecutors that evidence against him was derived from warrantless wiretapping.

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: More Violence in Baghdad
item.description: Car bombings and shootings in Baghdad on Wednesday killed at least 19 people, according to security and medical officials, adding to a death toll that has been rising quickly.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: World Briefing: New Government for Czech Republic
item.description: President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic appointed a new center-left government on Wednesday, ending a protracted period of political paralysis that has destabilized the country.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Top Intelligence Official Assails Snowden and Seeks Return of N.S.A. Documents
item.description: A scorching attack on Edward J. Snowden also cites unnamed accomplices in the disclosure of intelligence secrets.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: James R. Clapper Jr., center, the director of national intelligence, testified on Wednesday with other intelligence officials in an annual visit to Capitol Hill to discuss threats facing the country.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Tested Missile, Despite Treaty
item.description: The United States informed its NATO allies this month that Russia had tested a new missile, raising concerns about Moscow’s compliance with a landmark arms control agreement.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: The Lede: Video From Snowden’s German TV Interview
item.description: In excerpts from an interview with German television, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden dismissed President Obama’s proposed reforms and threats to his life published in Buzzfeed.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: News Analysis: Syrian Opposition’s Calm at Talks Surprises as Officials Falter
item.description: A turnabout has the exile coalition and its Western backers declaring an early, if modest, victory.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A cigarette break on Wednesday in an Aleppo neighborhood that was damaged by bombs.

item.title: Nahariya Journal: Despite Decades of Enmity, Israel Quietly Aids Syrian Civilians
item.description: The humanitarian disaster in Syria is eroding once-impervious psychological barriers between citizens of two bordering nations still technically at war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Syrian woman at a hospital in Nahariya, Israel, with her 8-year-old son, injured in a rocket attack that killed his older brother.

item.title: Russia Defers Aid to Ukraine, and Unrest Persists
item.description: A former Ukrainian president warned on Wednesday that the country is now on “the brink of civil war,” and five protesters were wounded in scuffles between two factions of antigovernment demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Ukrainian anti-government protesters walk out of the Ministry of Agriculture building in Kiev on Wednesday.

item.title: As China’s Economy Slows, the Pain Hits Home
item.description: China’s role as the largest buyer of a long list of commodities means that emerging markets are heavily exposed to any economic slowdown, but the most vulnerable producers may be the mines and farms in China itself.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: For Already Vulnerable Penguins, Study Finds Climate Change Is Another Danger
item.description: Intense rainfall and extreme heat combined with predation and starvation make life difficult for penguins, a University of Washington scientist says.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN
item.media:description: Weather extremes are leading to an increase in penguin chick mortality in a large breeding colony in Argentina.

item.title: Movement Seen in Talks Over Syria, Despite Gap
item.description: The top United Nations diplomat overseeing the talks, Lakhdar Brahimi, said that he expected little progress in the final few days of talks.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Matter: The Little Bit of Neanderthal in All of Us
item.description: Two studies show how the legacy of Neanderthals endures 30,000 years after their extinction, finding Neanderthal genes in skin and hair that may have helped humans evolve.
item.dc:creator: By CARL ZIMMER
item.media:description: A reconstruction of a Neanderthal skeleton, right, with a modern human skeleton in the background.

item.title: The Lede: A Dutch Jihadist in Syria Speaks, and Blogs
item.description: A Dutchman who quit the Royal Netherlands Army to join the jihad in Syria explains himself on Tumblr and in an English-language interview this week on Dutch television.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: "Half of Jihad is media." A Dutch jihadist's Tumblr photograph of the weapons he uses in Syria: His knife, his gun and his Instagram account.

item.title: World Briefing: Palestinian Shot Dead by Israeli Forces in West Bank
item.description: The Israeli military said the man opened fire first at a military post north of Ramallah; a Palestinian official said he was carrying a sign to redirect traffic.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Military Plans Reflect Afghanistan Uncertainty
item.description: Military planners, facing continued political uncertainty, have set in motion a plan designed to give NATO’s political leadership maximum flexibility, senior officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: Soldiers in Kandahar, Afghanistan, last week. Allied officials have drawn up plans for a force small enough for a quick exit.

item.title: The Lede: Messages of ‘Relentless, Spiraling Bloodshed’ from the Central African Republic
item.description: The emergency director for Human Rights Watch warns that sectarian violence in the African country has become a horrific back-and-forth of retaliation.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Migration of Monarch Butterflies Shrinks Again Under Inhospitable Conditions
item.description: The number of butterflies making a migration widely called one of the world’s great natural spectacles has become so small that the prospects of its rebounding are diminishing, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES
item.media:description: A Monarch butterfly in Mexico. The number of surviving butterflies has varied from year to year, sometimes wildly, but the decrease in the size of the migration in the last decade has been steep and generally steady.

item.title: Tension Builds in Israeli Coalition at a Critical Juncture in Peace Talks
item.description: The office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu issued a warning to a right-wing political partner, Naftali Bennett, over his harsh criticism of Mr. Netanyahu’s positions in recent days.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
